case_vignette: A 22-year-old female presents with    a brown rough spot on the left shin which she noted when shaving her leg. She thinks it may have been there for a few weeks.    She deni   es any pain, pruritus, or spontaneous  bleeding from the    site. She cannot recall any trauma that  may have caused the lesion.  She denies any personal or family history of skin cancer.      Physical exam reveals a thin, firm brown dome  shaped papule on the left shin that invaginates upon pinching.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have noticed a brown rough spot on my left shin.
How long have you had this rough spot?
I think it may have been there for a few weeks.
Has the size, shape, or color of the spot changed since you first noticed it?
I haven't noticed any changes in the size, shape, or color of the spot since I first saw it.
Do you have any personal or family history of skin cancer?
No, I don't have any personal or family history of skin cancer.
Do you feel any discomfort or itchiness from the spot?
No, I don't feel any pain or itchiness from the spot.
Have you had significant sun exposure or used tanning beds frequently in the past?
I cannot recall any specific trauma or significant exposure that may have caused the lesion.
**Final Diagnosis:** Actinic keratosis.
